description: Colleges and universities have been having a turbulent time deciding what speech and action are permissible on campus. Their difficulty mirrors that of the larger society in setting bounds for sometimes bitter disagreements. In a country that prizes open, robust debate, and is willing to risk some breaches of the peace to give room to free speech, what are the limits?

title: Three Killed, Dozens Hurt In Explosion
description: Three people were killed and at least 34 others were injured when an explosion followed by a huge fireball virtually destroyed two three-story brick apartment buildings in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, last night.

title: 2 True Signal-Callers Overthrow Misconceptions
description: Jim Kelly and John Elway made strong statements on Sunday and it was not only their production that led their teams to victories. It was also the style and the confidence both quarterbacks displayed in calling their own game from start to finish.

title: Chemists' New Toy Emerges as Superconductor
description: LIKE young children playing with their first balloons, thousands of chemists have been caught up in the fascination of a new toy that just might turn out to be a commercial bonanza: the "buckyball."

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SOVIET TURMOIL A6-10

title: SOVIETS' DISORDER IS FELT BY CUBANS
description: Last Thursday, when Cuba's Marxist-Leninist Government broke a 10-day silence over the political upheaval in the Soviet Union, it was to announce to the world that it would never veer from its "revolutionary and scientific" path, even after what it called the failure of Communist experiments elsewhere.

title: Slaying Divides A Neighborhood On Racial Lines
description: It is not readily apparent how much tension and trouble lurk in the working-class neighborhood where David Reilly lived and died in Southwest Philadelphia.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 1, 1991: TUESDAY Albertsons Inc Cincinnati Bell Inc Davis Water & Wst Inds Inc United Indl Corp WEDNESDAY Browning Ferris Inds Inc Handleman Co Helmerich & Payne Inc Kemper Corp LG & E Energy Corp Premier Indl Corp Stanhome Inc Starrett L S Co Trinity Inds Inc USF & G Corp THURSDAY Allegheny Pwr Sys Inc Baker Fentress & Co Bear Stearns Cos Chrysler Corp Engelhard Corp General Host Corp SPS Technologies Inc Witco Corp FRIDAY Berry Pete Co CRI Insd Mtg Assn Inc CRI Liquidating REIT Inc Green Mountain Pwr Corp Sysco Corp

title: Accounts
description: * Bozell Cheil, Seoul, South Korea, a joint venture of Bozell International and Cheil, has been awarded three accounts there: Tong Yang Magic appliances, $5.5 million; Hanbul Cosmetics, $2.7 million, and Federal Express, $500,000.

title: Into an Age of Fake Art: A Very Real Quandary
description: In a society that accepts fake fur and costume jewelry, what's wrong with fake art?

title: Susan Price Carr, Lawyer, 45
description: Susan Price Carr, a lawyer with Time Warner Inc., died on Friday at Beth Israel Hospital North in Manhattan. She was 45 years old.

title: British Visit Breaks the Ice With China
description: With a 19-gun salute at the edge of Tiananmen Square, Prime Minister John Major of Britain today became the first leader of a Western European country to visit China and shake hands with Prime Minister Li Peng in more than two years.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in SportsMonday about Erik McMillan's role in the Jets' victory over Tampa Bay misstated the amount of time wide receiver Al Toon is expected to miss because of an injury. He should be able to play Sunday.

title: Student Killed, Friend Injured In Queens Fight
description: Robin Moonasar and Shiraz Baksh were the best of buddies, fellow computer hackers and high school classmates in Toronto who decided to come to New York for a week of excitement before classes started on Wednesday.

title: An Old Tractor Becomes a $350,000 Mistake
description: Wayne Kuhlman, a lawyer here, occasionally likes to use his 1945 Farmall tractor to do odd jobs around his three-acre yard here, but he hardly thinks the rusty machine is worth the $9.6 million assessed by Clay County officials.

title: O'Connor Ends Stay in Rockland Hospital
description: John Cardinal O'Connor was released from Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y., yesterday morning after suffering from what a church spokesman said was heat prostration.

title: Mandela Visits 3 Imprisoned Rightists
description: Nelson Mandela intervened today in a hunger strike by three white right-wingers who have been charged by the South African authorities with killing blacks.

title: Jets' Effort Is Praised By Coslet
description: After becoming the first Jet coach since Weeb Ewbank in 1963-64 to win his home opening games in his first two seasons, Bruce Coslet was happy at camp today but he wasn't quite prepared to rest on his laurel.

title: BUSH PLAYS DOWN PROTEST ON AIDS
description: President Bush today brushed off a weekend demonstration near his home by advocates for people with AIDS, saying that he was concerned about local shopkeepers whose business was disrupted and that "behavioral change" is the best way to halt the disease's spread.

title: Money in Panama Dispute Is Frozen
description: The Government of Panama began a legal effort here today to try to recover $23 million that it contends was stolen from the country by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the deposed ruler. In all, Panama asserted that he had taken more than $500 million.

title: As U.S. Battles Computer Company, Writer Takes Vision of Evil to Grave
description: The death of a freelance writer in West Virginia on Aug. 10 has added an air of intrigue to a complicated, long-running court case that has become known in Washington circles simply as "Inslaw."

title: On My Mind; Pogrom in Brooklyn
description: The anti-Semitic outrages of Crown Heights are aimed at the Jews of only one neighborhood in one city -- for the moment.

title: Memphis State Stuns Southern Cal
description: At the start of the day, the University of Southern California was considered no less than a top-20 team in most polls. By the end of it, the Trojans had become a victim in the first big upset of the college football season.

title: Wes Anderson Dies; Art Director Was 39
description: Wes Anderson, the design director of The Village Voice from 1989 until this year, died on Friday. He was 39 years old.

title: Method of Matching Donor Kidneys Gains
description: A MORE accurate method for matching donor kidneys from cadavers to patients awaiting transplants may sharply improve the success rates of transplants between unrelated people, a new study suggests.

title: The Day's Highlights
description: Shaping the New Order

title: Q&A
description: Sea Gulls

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "This is a presidential putsch, a real presidential putsch. But thank God this one is without tanks. The politicians would have reached an agreement sooner or later and would have fooled the people into following them. But the dead cannot be resurrected. It's better to be fooled and alive than clear- minded and dead." -- Nikolai N. Engver, a Soviet legislator. [ A6:2. ]

title: Hendrick Christian Ahlers, Executive, 73
description: Hendrick Christian Ahlers, a retired executive in the wholesale dairy and cooking-oil business, died on Thursday at Meridian-The Woodland Care Center in Plainfield, N.J. He was 73 years old and lived in Chatham, N.J.

title: Reporter's Notebook; A Wariness Permeates The Usual Celebration
description: Inside her intricate but cumbersome headdress -- a 10-foot-tall, eight-pointed star fashioned out of nylon and foil -- Angela George was already uncomfortably hot at noon yesterday, just as the mass of festive humanity known as the West Indian- American Day parade was starting to make its way along Eastern Parkway in Crown Heights.

title: Books of The Times; A Biographer Seeking Himself in Another's Identity
description: Biography By Celia Gittelson 260 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $19.

title: Estonia's Foreign Minister Savors the Faxes, if Not the Champagne
description: For a man who hates champagne "so sour" -- these are trying times. Almost every day for the last week, Lennart Meri has been clinking glasses of bubbly with a foreign minister or two or their representatives to celebrate the reopening of diplomatic relations with Estonia.

title: The Ethnic Archipelago
description: Between Germany on the west and Siberia on the east lies a landlocked archipelago of tense ethnic islands: minority populations living uneasily under other peoples' flags. Centuries of migration and colonization have produced an ethnic checkerboard, confounding nationalist visions of homogeneous and compact states.

title: Markets Closed For Holiday
description: Because of the Labor Day holiday, financial markets in the United States were closed yesterday. Government offices, banks and many businesses were also closed. Articles about trading in overseas financial markets appears on page D9.

title: Bodies of 2 Men Are Found In Building Damaged by Fire
description: An early-morning fire on Sunday in a downtown apartment building killed one man and left seven homeless, officials said.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are this week's scheduled release dates for major economic indicators. Monday None

title: A Friendship, a Washington Bank and a Trail of Money Leading to B.C.C.I.; They Bought Stock With Insider Loans And Made Millions
description: Clark M. Clifford and Robert A. Altman resigned from their executive posts at First American Bankshares last month with their reputations tarnished, their pockets full, and some important questions unanswered, Government investigators say.

title: Slump Eases, but Hope Dims Among White-Collar Jobless
description: Economists are pointing cheerfully to a recovery they say has now moved firmly into gear. But for those left behind, like Courtney Anderson, a former $60,000-a-year airline vice president whose unemployment benefits have run out, the recession gets darker with each passing day of no work.

title: New York City Narrows Agency Finalists to 3
description: The New York City Public Development Corporation, which is seeking an advertising agency to help polish the city's image, is expected to select a winner in the next 10 days, industry executives say.

title: Market Place; Dreyfus Shifts Fee Strategy
description: THE Dreyfus Corporation is making money again in the mutual fund business.

title:
Real Estate;
Fed Builds New Bank In Dallas
description: CONSTRUCTION has started on a new headquarters building for the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas on the northern edge of downtown Dallas. The Fed's decision to choose a site for expansion within the city rather than outside it brought relief to many city leaders, but in brokerage circles there is concern over how the market will soak up the large block of space the bank is abandoning.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Pima County, Ariz., is offering $30 million in tax anticipation notes due on July 29, 1992, through Morgan Stanley & Co. The tax-exempt issue has a 5 percent coupon that is priced to yield 4.5 percent and is rated MIG-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and SP-1+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. COMMON STOCK

title: 25 Die, Many Reported Trapped, As Blaze Engulfs Carolina Plant
description: Twenty- five people were killed and 40 were injured early today as a fire believed to have started near huge grease-filled vats swept through a chicken-processing plant here.

title: Review/Film; Mysticism and Love Inside a Hammer and Sickle
description: Yuri Iliyenko's "Swan Lake: The Zone," which opens today at Film Forum 1, is a beautiful, dour Ukrainian film of both political and mystical import.

title: Microwave Cooking
description: THINK of the microwave oven as one pot, albeit a very efficient one. That means that if you are making dinner in a hurry for four, you will need more than your microwave oven, although a few of the dishes can be made in it.

title: Tougher Ban Avoided
description: Track's world governing body has doubled the penalty for illicit drug use, from a two-year suspension to a four-year suspension, but XINMEI SUI, the Chinese shot-putter who became the first World University Games competitor to test positive for steroids, will get off with a two-year ban.

title: Don't Look to Arizona As Health-Care Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Amid Crisis, Soviet Leaders Devote Prime Time to Television
description: The two leading figures in the political upheaval in the Soviet Union, Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Boris N. Yeltsin, have both decided to take a considerable amount of time in recent days away from the events transforming their country to give interviews to American television journalists.

title: Key Rates
Taming Bensonhurst's Annual Zucchini Glut
description: A BUMPER crop of zucchini isn't something you'd expect in Bensonhurst. The Brooklyn asphalt that stretches from 17th Avenue to Avenue U, between the water and 60th Street, appears to be sown only with row upon row of brick and stone houses. But just as most houses in this Italian neighborhood have a stoop and a well-polished car out front, most also have a zucchini patch behind.

title: Economic Scene; When Children Have Children
description: EVERYONE knows that teen-age pregnancy is the curse of the underclass -- that children who have children doom themselves to a life of poverty and dependence. But everyone, it seems, could be wrong.

title: Schedule, Once Connors's Friend, May Be What Finally Stops Him
description: Jimmy Connors showed up late for his practice session yesterday afternoon at the National Tennis Center. It was a wonder he bothered at all.

title: Sun to Enter Race to Offer Software
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. is beginning an attempt to become a major supplier of operating system software for computers, putting it into direct competition with Microsoft and a new joint venture of Apple and I.B.M.

title: City to Widen Investigation Of Contractor in Fatal Fall
description: New York City will step up its investigation of the contractor that is working on the Bronx construction site where a 12-year-old boy last week fell 500 feet to his death through an uncapped water shaft, officials said yesterday.

title: Yankees Can't Awaken Their Offense As Texas Nightmare Goes On and On
description: The Yankees stay in a hotel that enables them to walk to Arlington Stadium in about 30 seconds to play the Rangers. The walk in the muggy air seemed much longer after tonight's game. Fifteen-game losing streaks can make each step tougher.

title: Maverick Democrat Confronts Trenton's Welfare Rules
description: At the age of 43, Wayne R. Bryant is a senior partner in a thriving law firm with a Fortune 500 client roster, and he owns a major piece of a glistening new office tower in the town of Lawnside, where his family settled in the 1780's. He is wealthy, patrician and influential: Just the sort of man who would have no use for the welfare system. And Mr. Bryant clearly does not.

title: Lithuania's New Defense Minister: Young Man With a Nonviolent Strategy
description: In Lithuania, where no one has experience in running government agencies, it is perhaps not surprising that the Minister of Defense is a 31-year-old psychotherapist dedicated to nonviolent resistance.

title: SOVIET TURMOIL: Moscow Memo; The Old Order, Like Its Idols, Is Toppled, but the Victors Find Words of Bereavement
description: Revolutions are all about fallen symbols and collapsed order. And however great the relief, there is an inherent grief in any death.

title: Group W Pledges $1 Million For Radio Creative Award
description: HOPING to encourage further use of radio as an advertising medium, one of the country's largest owners of radio stations is pledging $1 million to start an annual national award for the most creative radio advertising.

title: High Blood Pressure May Pose Less of a Danger for Women
description: RESEARCHERS are adding high blood pressure to alcoholism, heart disease and other conditions that may affect women and men differently.

title: Editorial Notebook; Courage and Confusion at the Open
description: To tennis players and fans alike, there is no Grand Slam tournament quite like the raucous Septemberfest known as the U.S. Open. It is feast, festival and fashion show rolled into one; and after a day or a night in Flushing Meadows, spectators stumble from the premises drained and exhausted -- as if they, not 39-year-old Jimmy Connors, had been out there battling Aaron Krickstein for 4 hours and 41 minutes.

title: Washington Journal; Neighborhood Builds on Its Rubble
description: Two years ago, Ana Ventura and her family lived in squalor in a run-down apartment building in this city's Shaw neighborhood, trying to avoid the drug trafficking that occurred on every floor.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Anchor Bank, Myrtle Beach, S.C., has acquired the deposits and certain liabilities and assets of Hilton Head Bank and Trust Co., Myrtle Beach, from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. * Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A., Italy's largest insurer, said it had reached an agreement in principle with the Continental Corporation, New York, to jointly underwrite non-life-insurance risks of Generali's multinational clients in North America.

title: A Young Basketball Star Puts Ordeal Behind Him
description: It is a familiar scene played out in New York neighborhoods near summer's end. The city's finest basketball players leave their asphalt playgrounds and head for the Division I universities of their choice, fueled by four-year scholarships and the vision of major-college stardom.

title: Treasury Securities Gain Slightly
description: Prices of Treasury securities inched higher and interest rates fell a bit yesterday, despite a report showing that conditions in the manufacturing sector improved further in August.

title: Store Owner Finds Everybody Likes Him but the I.R.S.
description: Stew Leonard's is a giant dairy store here, with a petting zoo and dancing milk cartons, that each year sells 10 million quarts of milk, more than 1,000 tons of hamburger and 7.8 million ears of corn. (That's enough corn to stretch from Norwalk to Houston, give or take an ear.)

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: MENTION the word paprika and most people will think of Hungarian cooking. While the Hungarians are indeed extraordinarily fond of paprika -- it shows up in their goulashes, soups, white sauces and countless other dishes -- this potent spice does not come from that country. Paprika, both the hot and milder versions, is derived from a type of chili pepper that is native to South America. It is a distant cousin to the cayenne and red chili peppers.

title: Suspension Not Feared By Notre Dame's Mirer
description: As Rick Mirer continued to satisfy an unspecified punishment for breaking Notre Dame football team rules, the quarterback said he had not feared that his arrest last weekend for public intoxication and disorderly conduct would lead to a suspension.

title: A.T.&T. Helps Conner, Koch
description: The gap between Dennis Conner and Bill Koch was narrowed slightly yesterday when A.T.&T. chipped in with about $3 million to help sponsor the competing yachtsmen.

title: Saudis Increasing Oil Storage
description: With Soviet oil production falling precipitously, Saudi Arabia has significantly increased its stocks of oil in storage to around 60 million barrels and is signaling its determination to keep worldwide supplies plentiful and prices down.

title: An American Passion: Who Did What When?
description: CHRISTIE McCOY is big on anniversaries; her second anniversary on the job was in June. But the really important one is next week: the 150th anniversary of the tube. Not the kind that used to glow inside radios in the pre-transistor days, not the kind in tires, but the kind that artists' paint and toothpaste and stick-to-you-forever glues ooze out of.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The spotlight that never seems to waver from Britain's royal family has moved for the moment to PRINCESS ANNE and her estranged husband, Capt. MARK PHILLIPS. Because they have now been separated for more than two years, they are now free to file for divorce. Will they?

title: Industry Survey Shows Solid Growth in August
description: Helped by a surge in new orders, the nation's manufacturing economy expanded solidly in August, according to a monthly survey by the nation's purchasing managers. It was the third consecutive monthly expansion and economists saw it as another sign that the nation's economic recovery was under way at a steady, albeit gradual pace.

title: Nationwide Insurance Shifting to Ketchum
description: The Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company, Columbus, Ohio, has reassigned its national advertising account to Ketchum Advertising, Pittsburgh, from its agency of 28 years, Ogilvy & Mather, New York, effective in January.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday headed "Investments by 401(k) Plans," with an article about the safety of retirement plans, misstated the amounts invested in guaranteed investment contracts. Figures were in billions of dollars, not millions.

title: Wireless P.L.C. In Shifts at Top
description: Cable & Wireless P.L.C. said today that it was reorganizing its top management and appointing a new chief executive at its Mercury Communications unit.

title: Israel Request Raises Issue of Settlements
description: Israeli officials said today that they planned to request $10 billion in housing loan guarantees from the Bush Administration later this week, a move that could force the Administration to choose between its desire to get the Israelis to attend peace talks and President Bush's longstanding desire to tie any extra aid to a freeze on Israeli settlements in the occupied territories.

title: McMullen Giving Up Best Seat in the House
description: When all is said and done, owners of baseball's two expansion teams are each expected to pay out at least $120 million each for expenses, including a $95 million sign-up fee, before one pitch is thrown.

title: Grand Met Unit
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.'s International Distillers and Vintners unit said it had established a wholly owned subsidiary in Hungary. The new company, IDV Hungaria Ltd., will manage International Distillers' major brands in the local market. IDV Hungaria has signed a distribution agreement with Hungary's largest wine company, Hungarovin.

title: Thomas Denies Feud
description: ISIAH THOMAS said that if he is not invited to the 1992 Olympics, he will not blame MICHAEL JORDAN.

title: Europe Plans Yugoslav Peace Talks
description: The European Community decided today to convene a Yugoslav peace conference here beginning on Saturday to try to find a solution to the many conflicts dividing that country.

title: Continental Confirms Talks With Perot Son
description: H. Ross Perot Jr. has held talks with Continental Airlines about a possible venture that could be put together with several foreign carriers to inject new money into the bankrupt airline to make it more viable.

title: Massachusetts Says New Art Museum Must Help Pay Costs
description: Unless substantial private money is found to replace state funds, the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, the dream museum that would showcase large-scale collections of 20th-century art in North Adams, Mass., will not get off the drawing board.

title: How to Make Medicaid Popular
description: The dire problems of the Medicaid program reflect the lack of middle-class support for domestic programs for the poor. The solution -- becoming part of a universal health-care system in which the middle class has a stake -- can become a model of how to regain the public confidence necessary for further social advances.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article by Reuters in Business Day yesterday about an acquisition by a unit of Daimler-Benz misidentified the owner of the operations being acquired. It is the Diebold Group Inc., international management consultants in Bedford Hills, N.Y., not Diebold Inc., in Canton, Ohio. The two companies are not related.

title: Real Estate Executive Likes Deal With NCNB
description: Guerrino Savio, president of SCI Real Estate Development Ltd., the United States arm of one of Italy's biggest developers, says he got a bargain on Friday when his company paid $120 million to the NCNB Corporation for 1.8 million square feet of office space in Texas, plus eight land parcels.

title: Syntex in Pact With Theratech
description: Syntex U.S.A. Inc., a subsidiary of the Syntex Corporation, said it had entered into a collaborative agreement with Theratech Inc. for the development and manufacture of new pharmaceutical products. As part of the pact, Syntex will acquire an equity position in Theratech, a company based in Salt Lake City that specializes in skin patches and other controlled-release systems for administering drugs.

title: Wide Bartering Keeps Leningrad Going
description: For Leningrad's city council, where feeding the city and getting raw materials for its sputtering industries are top priorities, barter has been developed to a degree unforeseen even a year ago.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Aug. 24 about the job outlook in the service sector misstated actions by the Cigna Corporation. Cigna did not cut thousands of jobs when it began to phase out its auto insurance business; employees were transferred to other parts of the company.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Music Industry Bets on CD Sets
description: Come Christmas, the music industry is betting that consumers will decide a $50 boxed set of James Brown compact disks will look good under their trees. With 67 songs on four disks, "Star Time" has nearly all of Mr. Brown's hits, from "Please, Please, Please" to "Papa's Got a Brand-New Bag."

title: Fax Machines Are Getting a Voice
description: Companies trying to keep in closer contact with far-flung employees may soon have a new tool: the talking fax machine.

title: Families Seek Out Shelters As Route to Better Homes
description: New York City's shelter system for homeless families has become so livable that hundreds, if not thousands, of families who could stay elsewhere are flocking to shelters so they can move to the top of the list for permanent subsidized housing, city officials say.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR Diary: I was recently at the City University's Graduate Center in midtown Manhattan. Heading for the elevator I paused to hold a door open for a family: a mother carrying a toddler on her shoulders and her young son, who was pushing a stroller that contained his little sister. They all seemed in very high spirits. When I heard mother say to toddler, "I bet you never rode on a doctor's shoulders before!" it occurred to me that she had probably just received her Ph.D.

title: SOVIET TURMOIL: Soviet Notebook; When Meat Disappears, It's Waffles and Seaweed
description: The fabled long lines for food were not to be found early tonight at the Gastronom Shop No. 1 on Tverskaya Street. The reason was that the meat counter was selling waffles instead, and for a price that few Muscovites could afford.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the history of the Baltic republics referred incorrectly to the Estonian who led his country intermittently from 1918 to 1940. He was Konstantin Pats.

title: Books of The Times; Shaping Foreign Policy During the Civil War
description: William Henry Seward Lincoln's Right Hand By John M. Taylor Illustrated. 340 pages. HarperCollins. $25.

title: World Bank Lives High on the Taxpayers
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; Adapting an Anne Tyler Novel
description: If the sheer emotional weight of family, with all its burdens of love and pain and responsibility and memory, could somehow be represented by a single stage set, it could certainly look like Kevin Rigdon's design for "Earthly Possessions," the new play Frank Galati has adapted from Anne Tyler's novel for the Steppenwolf Theater Company.

title: Personal Health
description: WHILE parents may look forward to the first day of school, for millions of children, from preschool to college age, the thought of going to school brings apprehension and anxiety that can blossom into refusal to attend school or a crippling school phobia if misunderstood and mistreated. At least 5 percent of elementary school children and about 2 percent of high school students suffer from school phobia.

title: Eating Well
description: RETURN with me to the fateful summer of 1989 and Wednesday, Sept. 13.

title: For City Council From Queens
description: This year's City Council primary election in Queens has sparked a number of spirited contests, providing voters at least a few chances to raise the caliber of their representation. Here are our recommendations among Democratic candidates in districts where the Sept. 12 winner of the Democratic primary is virtually guaranteed election. 19th District: Anthony Avella Jr., a former aide to Mayors Edward Koch and David Dinkins, would bring a solid knowledge of city government to the Council and a refreshing independence that his chief opponent, Lawrence Gresser Jr., sorely lacks. Mr. Gresser, a real estate developer and hand-picked choice of the Democratic organization, is likely to favor its need over the district's.

title: Arbitrator Sends Stevens To Devils for Shanahan
description: Not a single puck has been dropped yet, but the Devils are already big winners in the National Hockey League as a result of an arbitrator's decision.

title: For Rosh ha-Shanah, a Table Laden With Kosher Tradition
description: LIKE many Jewish mothers around the world, Cyrel Deitsch of the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn is spending this week in the kitchen preparing for Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, which begins at dusk on Sunday. But unlike most American Jewish mothers, she has 12 children to feed, and with the addition of holiday guests, her table will stretch to welcome perhaps a dozen more people.

title: New Campaigns
description: * For the second year of an effort supporting Operation Exodus, which raises money for Soviet Jews resettling in Israel, the UJA-Federation is introducing a revamped campaign by Taylor-Gordon, Aarons & Company, New York. Several print advertisements focus on contributors who make statements like "Good economy, bad economy, if we don't help one another, who will?"

title: Market Place; Chemical Waste's Regulatory Woes
description: LIVE by regulations, die by regulations. That may be the underlying story at Chemical Waste Management Inc., which has been trading at about a point higher than its 52-week low of $16.75 in the last few weeks, although some analysts see a recovery in the long term.

title: Maine Crab Crawls Into America's Pots
description: LOBSTERS are not the only crustaceans taken in traps from the cold water off the coast of Maine. As long as lobstermen have been using lobster traps, they have been taking another shellfish in with their haul: crabs.

title: Donald J. Chipman, Businessman, 58
description: Donald J. Chipman, a New York businessman and investor, died on Monday at New York Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: How About Area Code Lists by Number?
description: To the Editor:

title: Safety of Queens Residents Finishes a Poor Second to Tennis
description: To the Editor:

title: Provincial Communist Is Born (Again) Free
description: For the people of Azerbaijan, these days since the eruption of the Soviet state have been a time of marvels.

title: Salomon Inquiry Widened
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that his agency was investigating whether the improper bids for Treasury securities submitted by Salomon Brothers were part of a broader effort by a group of investment houses to corner the bond market.

title: INSIDE
description: Murder Charge in IRT Crash

title: BRITON, IN CHINA, CALLS TIES NORMAL
description: Prime Minister John Major of Britain said today that relations between Britain and China were generally back to normal, but he also emphasized that in two days of talks with Chinese leaders he had pressed for improvements on human rights.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on the first sports page on Saturday with an article about Mike Powell's record long jump was published in error. It showed a subsequent jump by Powell at the meet; the record jump was shown only on the front page.

title: Book Notes
description: Autumn Leaves

title: Nomura Inquiry Reopened Amid Additional Findings
description: Amid new disclosures of possibly illegal stock market dealings, Japan's Finance Ministry has reopened an investigation of whether the Nomura Securities Company manipulated a stock on behalf of a well-known organized crime figure. The new developments raise the prospect that the brokerage may face serious new penalties.

title: Doctors Warned on Conflicts of Interest
description: The American Medical Association today warned doctors to be more alert to possible conflicts of interest when they refer patients to laboratories, clinics and other health-care businesses in which the doctors have invested.

title: OTHER SCENES FROM A REVOLUTION
description: APPARATCHIK: "I never thought I'd be out on the street and accused of being a member of a criminal organization," Mr. Portugalov said. "But I'm not shedding any tears for the party."

title: Driver Injures Four Girls in Rockaways and Flees
description: A car hit four girls on Monday in Edgemere, Queens, leaving an 11-year-old in critical condition and the others, ranging in age from 3 to 15, in serious condition, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Today you have a President. Tomorrow you may have another president. In any case, we are all one, side by side, and we shouldn't spit on one another. This is just my reaction to all of these doubts that have been cast upon my conduct." -- President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ A1:6. ]

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMISSION ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE LAW -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. AD HOC COMMITTEE FOR REVIEW OF PROGRAM FOR AFRICA RECOVERY AND DEVELOPMENT -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. General information phone: (212) 963-1234 Tours are conducted 9 A.M.-5:45 P.M.

title: About New York
description: The year was 1888, a time when Brooklyn was its own city crowing over a shimmering new bridge to Manhattan. It was a time when young men with few resources, with scarcely a morsel of English, could make an honest living with a shoeshine brush and a box of polishes.

title: Value of Cold Remedies Challenged
description: MEDICATION is probably unnecessary for a young child sniffling from a common cold, a new study suggests.

title: Wine Talk
description: FOR many New Yorkers, a brisk walk to the wine shop is a favorite fall exercise. "My cave (pronounced CAHV)," they like to say, "is practically empty." Even when they live on the 18th floor and the cave is the hall closet.

title: Cold Dawn in Moscow
description: Carried away by the failed coup against President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and its turbulent aftermath, many commentators are issuing sweeping and highly dubious conclusions about the "former Soviet system." Though some of these conclusions may one day turn out to be valid, they are based more on today's euphoria than on Soviet realities.

title: Food Notes
description: R & R for Red Snapper

title: Bridge
description: Each year thousands of players are allocated random partners by a pairing desk at a tournament or by a club manager. One such pairing two years ago at Jourdan's Club, in Boca Raton, Fla., may have set a remarkable record.

title: Exiled General Urges the Lebanese to Resist
description: Starting a new era of opposition in exile, Michel Aoun, the renegade Christian general who was spirited to asylum in France last week, called on the Lebanese today to reject the Government of President Elias Hrawi and vowed to liberate the country and regain its lost sovereignty.

title: Haarhuis Says He's Surprised
description: Paul Haarhuis watched on television as Jimmy Connors played his epic match Monday night against Aaron Krickstein.

title: Operation Rescue Condemns Death Threats; Oppressed by Zealots
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Memo; Undaunted by Doubters, Wilder Ponders '92
description: A call for budget cuts and fiscal responsibility is probably not the most compelling message for the more liberal voters of the Democratic Presidential primaries.

title: The Day's Highlights
description: A Crucial Vote Nears

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's not often that the postal service elicits chuckles from the letter-writing public, but that may change with the issuance of a series of five 29-cent stamps depicting renowned comedians as seen through the eyes of AL HIRSCHFELD.

title: Jets' Rookie Linebacker Fills the Bill
description: After his performance in Sunday's 16-13 victory over Tampa Bay, Mo Lewis appears to be the strong player the Jets need to fill the strong-side linebacking spot.

title: In New Position, Johnson Does Right Thing
description: Howard Johnson became the Mets' right fielder of the present and most likely the future last night. He was an instant hit, especially the instant he doubled home the first run of a three-run outburst in the first inning and the instant he singled across the first run of a three-run flurry in the fifth.

title: Dow Plummets 25.93 to Finish at 3,017.67
description: Stock prices fell yesterday amid persistent concerns about the pace of the nation's economic recovery and the impact of computerized trading.

title: Yields Drop On C.D.'s and Bank Funds
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts fell in the week ended yesterday.

title: Thousands Protest Cuts In Dallas School Budget
description: Thousands of high school students, some throwing bottles and stones, marched on the headquarters of the Dallas Independent School District today to protest the layoffs of 245 teachers and the elimination of 384 teaching positions.

title: Studios Courting Woody Allen
description: His movies do not make much money by Hollywood standards, and his demands for creative freedom, coming from anyone else, would be laughed out of town. But Woody Allen is a film maker with cachet, and in an industry that fancies itself equal parts art and commerce, recent word that he might end his long relationship with Orion Pictures has set off maneuvering by other studios eager to sign him to a deal.

title: Three Tests of Soviet Survival
description: Can the Soviet Union survive? Its political leaders are straining to construct a new political association of independent republics. Great constitutional and human rights issues are at stake as delegates to a national congress pass on how to reshape their country. But the ultimate answer to survival will be economic: whether what one leader calls the "corpse" of the Soviet economic system can be brought to life.

title: Bridgeport Starts Appeal in Bankruptcy Case
description: Bridgeport renewed efforts today to resolve its troubled finances in bankruptcy court, appealing a Federal judge's decision that it did not qualify for bankruptcy protection.

title: Jurors Indict Motorman For Murder
description: The subway motorman whose Manhattan train derailed last week, killing five people, was indicted yesterday on murder charges, a more serious charge than the manslaughter counts on which he was arrested after the crash.

title: Bush Stresses Schools As Critics Turn Up Heat
description: Facing renewed charges from Democrats that he is inattentive to domestic problems, President Bush today kicked off a weeklong effort to promote his Administration's education programs with a visit to a Maine high school and a kindergarten, where he read a children's story aloud.

title: Pressmen Suing New York Times On Arbitration
description: A second lawsuit has been filed over efforts by The New York Times to take its unions to arbitration over a new $450 million printing plant in Edison, N.J.

title: Dolphins' Hill Is Traded For Cards' No. 1 Pick
description: The Miami Dolphins traded wide receiver RANDAL HILL, their first-round draft pick, to Phoenix yesterday for the Cardinals' top selection in next year's college draft.

title: In Queens District, Visions of Future Races
description: While five candidates in District 21 in Queens try to woo voters in the City Council race, another political campaign is under way in the district. In Jackson Heights, Corona, Elmhurst and East Elmhurst, Hispanic leaders have begun courting people like Luis Santos, who cannot vote in this election because they are not American citizens.

title: Laura Riding, 90; Poet and Founder Of New Criticism
description: Laura Riding Jackson, a poet, critic and co-founder with Robert Graves of various literary publishing ventures, died on Monday at the Humana Sebastian Hospital in Sebastian, Fla. She was 90 years old and had lived in Florida since 1938.

title: A Defender of the Faith With Fond Memories Of Her Discipleship
description: MARION CUNNINGHAM, whose lively revision of the prim and outmoded "Fannie Farmer Cookbook" has made it once again a kitchen standard, is talking on her kitchen phone.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: Soviet Turmoil A12-17

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL American League

title: Accounts
description: * Sunbeam/Oster Household Products Group, Milwaukee, to Cramer-Krasselt, Milwaukee, for its Sunbeam and Oster brands of kitchen appliances. The agency said that the $6 million account had previously been handled by Tatham/RSCG, Chicago, for Sunbeam, and Hoffman York & Compton, Milwaukee, for Oster. * Jantzen Inc., Portland, Ore., the bathing suit and casual wear subsidiary of the VF Corporation, to Bozell Inc., New York. The agency said that the company, which has a $4 million advertising budget, previously created its own advertising. Bozell handles the accounts for other VF brands.

title: The Pop Life
description: A Music Sampler

title: Gerald Jacobs Is Dead; Tea Executive Was 71
description: Gerald Jacobs, a New York businessman and investor, died of a massive heart attack on Saturday a few blocks from his Manhattan office in a taxi en route to Beth Israel Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Public & Private; Noun, Vulgar, Defined
description: When I was a child I would sometimes go to the dictionary to look for mysterious words. These were never words like "deduce" or "obstinate," "sauerbraten" or "wadding." These were almost always the kinds of words you hear bigger kids saying behind the garage, bigger kids who threaten you with injury if you mention in front of an adult that you heard those words from them. As a result I would frequently find myself in the bathroom with the old red-covered dictionary looking for a word like -- well, you know. And I could never find it.

title: Goodyear Tire To Raise Prices
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said today that it would raise prices on its tires from 4 percent to 8 percent.

title: Alfonso Garcia Robles Dies at 80; Shared Nobel for Atom Arms Ban
description: Alfonso Garcia Robles, a former Mexican Foreign Minister who shared the 1982 Nobel Peace Prize for promoting disarmament, died late Monday in Mexico City. He was 80 years old.

title: Forstmann Little in Deal For a Share of Whittle
description: Forstmann Little & Company has signed an initial agreement to invest $350 million for a one-third interest in Whittle Communications, the media company that was founded by Christopher Whittle.

title: Beef Council Nearing End of Agency Search
description: This week, the Beef Industry Council, Chicago, will finish interviewing eight agencies vying for its $25 million-plus advertising account, advertising executives familiar with the review said yesterday. They said finalists are expected to be chosen by the end of next week.

title: R. R. Donnelley Picks New Division Officers
description: R. R. Donnelley & Sons Company, the Chicago-based printing concern, announced top management changes yesterday for its magazine and telecommunications divisions.

title: Gorbachev and Yeltsin, Tense Allies, Push Union Plan
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian federated republic acknowledged differences today but joined together in urging the adoption of a new governing structure for the Soviet Union, based on the resurgent power of its constituent republics.

title: Operation Rescue Condemns Death Threats; Unborn Troops
description: To the Editor:

title: Smallest Ever In Disk Drives
description: A small Colorado disk drive company said yesterday that it had begun shipments of the smallest hard disk drives, which are about the size of a deck of cards.

title: Motorman's Case Reflects City's Horror, Experts Say
description: The grand jury indictment of Robert E. Ray on second-degree murder charges was a predictable reflection of the horror across New York City at the conduct of the subway motorman and the deaths and injuries underground, legal experts said yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; No Tolls On Handley's Bridge, Yet
description: IN time, the test of the Giants' transition to Ray Handley from Bill Parcells will occur in the Super Bowl XXVI playoffs, or if a losing streak develops. But there are no tollbooths yet on the bridge to the rookie head coach from the best coach in the history of the franchise.

title: Nemiroff Memorial
description: A memorial service for Robert Nemiroff, the Broadway producer, is to be held on Friday at 1 P.M. at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, on 47th Street west of Broadway. Among those scheduled to participate are Ossie Davis, Ruby Dee, Ernestine Jackson, Delroy Lindo and the composer Judd Woldin. Mr. Nemiroff, a longtime champion of the works of Lorraine Hansberry, to whom he was married, died on July 18 at the age of 61.

title: People
description: * Jed Bernstein, 36, and Monty Kiernan, 41, senior vice presidents and management directors at Ally & Gargano, New York, have been appointed to the newly created positions of co-directors of new-business development. * Joie Davidow, founder, executive publisher and editor in chief of L.A. Style magazine, which was acquired by the American Express Publishing Company in 1988, announced yesterday that she would resign after producing the magazine's December issue.

title: Breaching the Brain's Wall to Deliver Drugs
description: Researchers seeking treatments for diseases of the central nervous system have long been stymied by the blood-brain barrier, which blocks or limits the flow of substances from capillaries into the tissues of the brain. While some substances, like caffeine and alcohol, easily cross the barrier, many therapeutic drugs do not.

title: Avent Headed for Italy
description: The agent for Milwaukee Bucks rookie ANTHONY AVENTsays his client will play in Italy next season because the National Basketball Assoication team cannot fit a contract for the 6-foot-10-inch forward under the salary cap.

title: Capriati Stuns Sabatini and Goes to Semifinals
description: The defending United States Open champion, Gabriela Sabatini, pushed and pinned to the baseline like a prize butterfly in Jennifer Capriati's ever-expanding tennis scrapbook, was stripped of her only Grand Slam title last night in a 6-3, 7-6 (7-1) upset dealt out by a 15-year-old who played with a wisdom beyond her years.

title: Communists in Spain Roiled By Calls of Some to Disband
description: The Spanish Communist Party, which managed to survive defeat in a civil war followed by almost four decades of rightist dictatorship and 16 years of democracy, has now been thrown into disarray by calls for its dissolution after the failed Soviet coup.

title: Verdict Is Guilty in Cheerleading Trial
description: After being portrayed by prosecutors as a venomous stage mother, a 37-year-old woman was convicted tonight of trying to hire someone to kill the mother of her daughter's chief rival in a cheerleading competition,

title: Rome Journal; A Poisoned Season: Dead Dolphins, Abused Pups
description: For most of the last month, when people fled the cities and mass vacations stilled the fizz of urban life, Italy's silly season turned as usual to tales of animal woe -- pet puppies abandoned by beach-bound owners, rats proliferating below the streets.

title: A Software Leader To Buy Pansophic
description: Computer Associates International Inc., the world's largest publisher of mainframe software, said yesterday that it had reached a tentative agreement to purchase Pansophic Systems Inc., a publisher of systems software for large computers, in a deal valued at $283 million, or $16.15 a share.

title: Corrections
description: An entry on Aug. 28 in the Addenda listing of the Media Business page about a dispute between Volvo Cars of North America and its former advertising agency, Scali, McCabe, Sloves in New York, referred incorrectly to a report in Adweek. The magazine said Volvo was "not ruling out suing" the agency; it did not say the company was preparing a suit.

title: Study Calls for More TV Time for '92 Candidates
description: A Harvard study today called for presidential candidates and the television networks to agree to schedule substantial televised appearances by the candidates each Sunday in the fall 1992 campaign.

title: French Team Criticized
description: The way the French sports daily L'Equipe saw it, the French 400-meter relay team not only placed second to the American team in the world-record race in Tokyo last week, it also managed to disgrace itself by its cavalier conduct after the race.

title: Thomas Backers' Ad Faults Senators
description: Two conservative groups that support the selection of Judge Clarence Thomas for the Supreme Court have begun running a television commercial questioning the ethics of three Democratic Senators whom they expect to oppose the nomination.

title: 3 Baltic Nations Seek U.N. Seats
description: The three Baltic nations, Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, applied for full membership in the United Nations today.

title: Review/Theater; 2 Jersey Girls Leave Home
description: At the end of the tedious first act of "The Jersey Girls," a dreadful play by Larry Manogue at the Actors' Playhouse, Glen and Lisa begin teasing their old chum Mim about the time she lost her bra on a date in high school. Angered by the indelicacy of such revelations, the prudish Mim huffily declares, "Some things just aren't funny." Unfortunately, "The Jersey Girls" is one of them.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Abington Bancorp, Abington, Mass., announced that Donald R. Eldridge had resigned as its president and chief executive and as chief executive and chairman of its Abington Savings Bank unit. It also announced that James P. McDonough, president and chief operating officer of the savings bank, had been named to the additional positions of chief executive at the bank and president and chief executive of Abington Bancorp. * Eyring Corp., Provo, Utah, a maker of flight and weapons systems simulators, named Gregory M. Patchen president and chief executive.

title: Winning on Last Play Not New to Giants
description: Don't make Super Bowl reservations yet because the Giants still have 15 regular-season games to play. But their performance Monday night in a last-play, 16-14 victory over the San Francisco 49ers certainly spoke well for their chances to repeat.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Psychiatric Chain To Buy 2 Competitors
description: Community Psychiatric Centers said today that it had agreed to buy two related hospital companies with financial problems -- Healthcare International Inc. and Healthvest -- in a transaction estimated at about $175 million.

title: Debt Revamping If Bottlers Merge
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. is considering refinancing some of the Johnston Coca-Cola Bottling Group's high-yield debt if it acquires Johnston Coca-Cola, said Doug Scovanner, treasurer at Coca-Cola Enterprises. Coca-Cola Enterprises on Friday offered to acquire Johnston Coca-Cola for $439 million in stock. The company would assume Johnston's $1 billion debt.

title: Philippines And Banks Revise Debt
description: The Philippines and a committee of bankers led by Manufacturers Hanover have agreed on a plan to reorganize nearly $5 billion of loans.

title: Operation Rescue Condemns Death Threats
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MARKETS

title: Though Jobless, a High-Level Apparatchik Sheds No Tears for His Party
description: Nikolai S. Portugalov was a member of the Soviet Communist Party for 40 of his 63 years, holding the rank of senior counselor in its once all-powerful Central Committee when the whole structure crashed in ruins last month after the failed coup against President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Ex-California Governor To Seek the Presidency
description: With a blast at "monstrous" political campaigns and a "corrupt" political system, Edmund G. Brown Jr. said today that he was dropping his bid for the Senate to open an exploratory candidacy for President. The former California Governor said he wanted to serve as the voice for the disaffected and would accept no contribution larger than $100.

title: Japanese Cars Stronger In Weak U.S. Economy
description: Japan's auto companies are emerging from the recession in the United States with a far bigger slice of that market than they had two years ago, but the political problems from their success in the United States have persisted.

title: Bystander Shot in Brooklyn
description: A 72-year-old Brooklyn woman leaving a grocery store was hit yesterday by a bullet intended for a young man who was also wounded in the shooting the police said. The woman, Connie Braccia, was struck in the chest by the gunfire outside 790 13th Avenue in Bay Ridge at 3:30 P.M. The wounded man, who was involved in the fight that led to the shooting, was hit in the stomach, the police said.l Both were in serious but stable condition last night.

title: Lumber Tax To Be Ended By Canada
description: Canada told the United States today that it would cancel a tax on lumber exports, a move that could reignite a longstanding political battle over lumber trade and complicate negotiations for a continental free-trade area that would also include Mexico.

title: Lutherans Vote Abortion Stance, Seeking New Language in Debate
description: In a statement intended to "get beyond" the current polarization of the abortion debate, the 5.2 million-member Evangelical Lutheran Church in America said yesterday that abortion could be a morally responsible choice in a limited number of cases.

title: Jimmy Connors Show: The Rage of the Open
description: Late in Jimmy Connors's marathon match with Aaron Krickstein on Monday, Connors broke through the invisible wall between athlete-actor and television audience. He looked directly into a courtside camera and proclaimed: "This is what they come for. This is what they want."

title: Frank Capra, Whose Films Helped America Keep Faith in Itself, Is Dead at 94
description: Frank Capra, the Academy Award- winning director whose movies were suffused with affectionate portrayals of the common man and the strengths and foibles of American democracy, died yesterday at his home. He was 94 years old and lived in La Quinta, Calif., a suburb of Palm Springs.

title: District Finds Way to End Segregation and Restore Neighborhood Schools
description: Arguing that housing segregation was the cause of segregated schools, the Palm Beach County public school system has devised a plan to integrate housing in the county, a move that school officials hope will mean that children can again attend neighborhood schools.

title: Natural Gas Buildup Blamed for Brooklyn Blast
description: A buildup of natural gas probably caused the explosion and fire that killed three people and injured 31 in two Brooklyn apartment buildings on Monday, fire officials said yesterday.

title: Leigh Wade, Air Force General And Aviation Pioneer, Dies at 93
description: Leigh Wade, a pioneer aviator who became an Air Force major general, died Saturday in the Belvoir Woods Health Care Center at Fort Belvoir, Va. He was 93 years old and lived in Washington.

title: 1 Killed and 2 Wounded in S.I. Dispute Over Dog
description: A feud between two families on Staten Island over a dog urinating on a bush led to a shootout in which one man was killed and two others, including a bystander, were wounded, the police said.

title: General Magnaplate reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Toward a Soviet Re-Union
description: The collapse of the centrally controlled Soviet Union leaves a frightening void. It's no wonder that Soviet leaders are struggling to create a new confederation that decentralizes power but retains elements of unified control. Americans who welcome the impulse to escape the stifling grip of centralized power can also welcome these aspects of a limited re-union.

title: A Trumpeter's Treasure Trove
description: As a child he wandered the mean streets of Storyville in New Orleans. His formal education ended in the fifth grade. As early as the 1920's, his performance contracts forbade him to use the back entrance to clubs and concert halls. Time magazine put him on its cover in 1949. He protested publicly when Gov. Orval E. Faubus blocked integration of the Little Rock schools in 1957, and President Dwight D. Eisenhower sent him a conciliatory telegram. Miles Davis said it was impossible to play anything on the trumpet that he hadn't already played.

title: NEW INCINERATORS TERMED ESSENTIAL IN NEW YORK CITY
description: New York City will have to build as many as three new garbage incinerators, in part because it will not be able to recycle as much trash as state goals call for, the Dinkins administration has concluded.

title: Defense Lawyers And the Mob
description: John Gotti's troubles in getting a lawyer were nothing compared with the dilemma faced by lower-level defendants in mob trials. Some defense lawyers in drug and racketeering cases make a business of taking money from kingpins to represent their underlings.

title: Genelabs Technologies Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Let Landlords Share In Tree Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: Tacoma Boatbuilding Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: A GARAGE door that slides smoothly up and down is a morale booster as well as a back saver. Because of their many parts, garage doors need lubrication and minor adjustments once or twice a year. The job is usually easy, but some procedures can require two people to complete.

title: Questa Oil & Gas Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Davis Factor, 89, Cosmetics Chief Who Built Up Father's Company
description: Davis Factor Sr., who helped build his father's business, Max Factor & Company, into an international cosmetics empire, died Saturday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 89 years old.

title: A Director of Research Is Named at Microsoft
description: The Microsoft Corporation yesterday appointed Richard Rashid, a professor of computer science at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, to the new position of director of research.

title: Warner Computer Systems reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Pop in Review
description: Zaiko Langa Langa S.O.B.'s

title: Thinking '92: Voters Have Got to Care Again; Remember Churchill
description: To the Editor:

title: Company Jet With 12 Americans Reported Missing Over Malaysia
description: A small plane carrying 12 Americans, including four high-ranking oil executives of Conoco and their wives, was reported missing over Malaysia today.

title: Britain Ousts Salomon From Role in Stock Sale
description: The British Government announced tonight that it had dismissed Salomon Brothers from its prestigious and potentially lucrative position as lead manager in the United States of the planned sale of British Telecommunications P.L.C. shares.

title:
CURRENTS;
A Return to the Past Renews a Lobby
description: "THE lobby was like a steakhouse on I-95," said the architect James Wollens. His firm, Wollens Associates, has just restored the ground floor of Essex House, an apartment building at 325 East 41st Street, in Tudor City.

title: Thinking '92: Voters Have Got to Care Again; The Roosevelt Upset
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Plans Big Deficit
description: With Israel poised to ask the United States for $10 billion in loan guarantees to help absorb new Soviet immigrants, the Government approved a budget proposal today that some political commentators here warned could undercut Israel's case in Washington.

title: Judge Orders a Lawyer Sent To Prison for Racketeering
description: One of New York City's leading personal-injury lawyers, Morris J. Eisen, was sentenced to almost five years in prison yesterday on racketeering charges that involved bribing witnesses and falsifying evidence.

title: Rams Are Ramming on Defense
description: The Giants started preparing today for Sunday's game here against the Philadelphia Eagles. Well, not exactly against the Eagles, but the Eagles' defense.

title: Residential Mortgage Investments Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mediplex Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: ABC Program Still on Hold
description: ABC News again postponed its special interview program with the Soviet leaders Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Boris N. Yeltsin, which had been tentatively scheduled for last night, because the Congress of People's Deputies had not adjourned.

title: And Now, What Ails Cone?
description: On a sobering night of dire medical reports on two-fifths of their starting rotation, the Mets last night also had to cope with the less dramatic but fully exasperating case of David Cone. His ailment? Performance schizophrenia.

title: Bridge
description: Of the 24 players who will represent the United States in the world team championship beginning in Yokohama, Japan, on Sept. 29, exactly half will be subsidized by the American Contract Bridge League. One of the unlucky ones is Alex Ornstein of Roslyn, L.I., a law student, but his bridge club has decided to help. The Beverly, at 130 East 57th Street, will hold a club championship at 8 P.M. tomorrow, with all the proceeds to go to Ornstein.

title: North Carolina Examines Inspection Lapses in Fire
description: The state Labor Secretary said today that the failure to inspect a chicken-processing plant where 25 people died in a fire was a result of his department's shortage of money and staff as well as the Federal Government's failure to hold it to stricter standards.

title: Pressure on Pentagon
description: After months in which American military spending seemed unassailable, the decline of the Soviet monolith may prompt the Bush Administration to take a closer look. Some experts question whether new generations of weapons or strategic defense systems can now be justified.

title: Whittle Holding Talks On a Bid for Healthlink
description: Whittle Communications is in "serious final-stage negotiations" to acquire Healthlink Television, its only serious rival in selling advertiser-supported media products to doctors' waiting rooms, a Whittle executive said yesterday.

title: Dow Edges Down 9.17 to Close at 3,008.50
description: Stocks closed lower yesterday after the Dow Jones industrial average dipped to the psychological barrier of 3,000 and then rebounded slightly to close at 3,008.50, a loss of 9.17 points.

title: How Gooden's Injury Will Be Judged
description: It is too early to tell whether Dwight Gooden's recent injury will have a lasting impact on his career, doctors say, but a procedure to be performed this weekend should clarify the situation.

title: Sports of The Times; Can Connors Dominate The Chair?
description: IT has long been my contention that the fans at home often see more of a sports event than the people in the stadium do. This was certainly true on Monday, when people watching television knew that Jimmy Connors had lapsed over the line of acceptability, helped by the officials.

title: Baker's Remarks: Policy on Soviets
description: Following is a statement made today by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d during a briefing on United States policy toward the Soviet Union.

title: Europe's Electronics Rescue Plan
description: European governments are stepping up efforts to rescue the Continent's beleaguered electronics industry. They fear that further deterioration could leave Europe hopelessly behind Japan and the United States, not only in electronics but also in automobiles, aerospace and the many other industries that depend on electronic components.

title: Still Kowtowing to Beijing
description: When Prime Minister John Major of Britain arrived in Hong Kong yesterday after a visit to Beijing, he did not receive a warm welcome. The people of Hong Kong understand that working relations between Britain and China are vital if the transfer of sovereignty over the territory in 1997 is to proceed smoothly. Yet the Chinese-British relationship amounts to British appeasement of Beijing's demands for control over Hong Kong and to Britain's selling out of the interest of the people of Hong Kong.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about the friendship between Clark M. Clifford and Robert A. Altman referred incorrectly to Mr. Altman's son. He is James Clifford Altman.

title: Jack Henry & Associates reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,473,000.

title: Hiao-Tsiun Ma, 80; Founded Orchestra For Young Players
description: Dr. Hiao-Tsiun Ma, a musicologist, conductor and teacher who founded the Children's Orchestra in New York and who was the father of the cellist Yo-Yo Ma, died on Aug. 28 at Long Beach Hospital on Long Island. He was 80 years old.

title: Maxco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Oil-Spill Organization Gearing Up
description: In partial fulfillment of a pledge made after the Exxon Valdez spill of March 1989, a not-for-profit oil industry organization announced yesterday that it had placed orders for 16 ships, complete with oil skimmers and containment boom systems, plus 20 miles of shoreline booms and other equipment, at a cost of $216 million.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, plans to announce today the interest rate for $650 million in seven-year debentures due Sept. 10, 1998.

title: Pep Boys-Manny, Moe & Jack reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Texfi Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-Included a one-time restructuring charge of $ 7,621,000, which related to the termination of certain fleece apparel operations.c-Net incomeThe company also said that it realized about $ 1.6 million in cash from the sale of a plant in New Bern, N.C.

title: Richmond Paper to Close
description: Media General Inc., the newspaper and broadcasting company in Richmond, said yesterday that it would close The Richmond News Leader in June and merge the afternoon newspaper into the morning Richmond Times-Dispatch. The company also announced an early retirement incentive program for employees.

title: Glenmore Distilleries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a pre-tax charge to operations to reduce the carrying value of real estate associated with a closed manufacturing facility.

title: Lawter International reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Maple Leaf Foods reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago periods are pro forma results, representing the combined operations of Canada Packers Inc. and Maple Leaf Mills Ltd. as if the two companies had been combined on Jan. 1, 1990.Results are in Canadian dollars.The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: More Than an Ex-Dictator's Future At Stake as Trial of Noriega Begins
description: After a full-scale invasion of his country and 20 months of preliminary legal skirmishes, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the former dictator of Panama, will finally go on trial here this week, charged with 10 counts of drug trafficking, money laundering and racketeering that could get him 140 years in prison.

title: Trico Products Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and included income tax benefits from utilization of loss carryforwards of $ 442,000 in the quarter and $ 875,000 in he 6 months.

title: Wilson Brothers reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a reversal of a tax credit of $ 47,000.

title: Hampton Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
Geriatric & Medical Centers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 6,000 in the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $ 1,400,000, or 12 cents a share, in the year.c-Net lossd-After an extraordinary charge of $ 508,000 and an extraordinary credit of $ 2,492,000, or 21 cents a share, in the quarter and year, respectively.Year-ago loss from continuing operations of $ 690,000 and income from continuing operations of $ 3,736,000, or 31 cents a share, in the quarter and year, respectively, both included $ 1,300,000 charge for the settlement of medicaid audit adjustments and a city business use and occupancy tax.Share earnings and shares outstanding are retroactively adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split declared April 22, 1991.The company said in fiscal 1991, net income included a gain of $ 4,448,000 from the sale of assets, compared with a $ 10,479,000 gain in fiscal 1990.

title: Saving Old Documents
description: Northeast Document Conservation Center 100 Brickstone Square, Andover, Mass. 01810; (508) 470-1010.

title: Food Experts to Study Soviet Distribution System
description: Two teams of agricultural experts ordered to the Soviet Union by President Bush this week will be led by Department of Agriculture officials concerned that the distribution of food there may be as much a problem as food supply.

title: Cunningham Surgery
description: RANDALL CUNNINGHAM underwent major surgery on his left knee yesterday and the surgeon said the Eagles quarterback should be ready by next year's training camp.

title: Zavitz Technology reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net incomeResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: Thinking '92: Voters Have Got to Care Again; Run, Bill, Run
description: To the Editor:

title: Voplex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Karachi Journal; A Hindu Romeo, a Muslim Juliet and Woe Aplenty
description: Zeba Bakhtiar, the angel-faced Pakistani star of the hit summer film "Henna," received her first set of reviews even before filming began. They were death threats.

title: Europeans, Ending a Delay, Approve Soviet Technical Aid
description: The European Community approved $11.8 million in technical assistance for the Soviet Union today, the first installment of a long-delayed $1.062 billion program.

title: House of Fabrics reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Charron, Schwartz In New Perfume Effort
description: Charron, Schwartz & Partners, New York, has been named to create advertising to introduce another fragrance into a crowded $5 billion perfume market.

title: Occidental Is Selling IBP Stake
description: In an expected step to narrow its operations, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that it would sell its majority stake in the beef processor IBP Inc. to stockholders and, if necessary, other investors.

title: Maris's Feat Finally Recognized 30 Years After Hitting 61 Homers
description: Thirty years after he hit 61 home runs, Roger Maris gained recognition yesterday as the holder of baseball's official home run record. But Andy Hawkins lost a no-hitter he pitched a year ago.

title: Thinking '92: Voters Have Got to Care Again; Unpopular Populist
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotations of the Day
description: "It offers full participation to all South Africans at all levels of government and does so on a universally acceptable basis." -- President F. W. de Klerk, outlining proposals for a new South African constitution. [ A9:1. ]

title: National Computer Systems reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax charge of $ 750,000 from the restructuring of its European business.

title: In Lieu of Swags and Cloth, Just Simple Country Coziness
description: EVEN the decorating world is acknowledging the recession, in an oblique way. Signs of tight finances, if no lack of fantasy, can be detected at Show house 91 in Smithtown, L.I., a benefit for Family Service League of Suffolk County that opens Monday.

title: Nordstrom Opens Bank for Its Credit Cards
description: Nordstrom Inc., the Seattle-based specialty retailer, opened a nationally chartered bank Tuesday to issue and service its credit cards. The move will exempt the company from state limits on finance charges for consumer credit.

title: Boston Journal; Pat on the Back Strains Police Force
description: It was billed as a community-organized event, and it certainly seemed like a genuine grass-roots show of affection: 300 poster-toting citizens gathered in front of Boston's police headquarters last week to demonstrate their support.

title: Parents Weigh the Risks Of City vs. Suburbs
description: PEOPLE with children have always debated leaving New York City. But previous generations saw their trek to the suburbs as a move up to a better life.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Events: Harvest Time, Decorative Iron
description: Of and From the Garden Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, off Eastern Parkway, Prospect Heights; (718) 622-4433.

title: Architects Conquer The Smear Problem
description: A smudged drawing is to an architect what a fallen cake is to a chef: a minor disaster. To prevent smears, two architects, Cindy Coleman of Chicago and Sava Cvek of Boston, have designed a 16-inch ruler, or scale, and a 45-degree triangle with tiny retractable ball bearings.

title: Bible Videos Called Offensive to Jews
description: A series of animated Bible stories on videotapes that has sold hundreds of thousands of copies over the past three years has been assailed for what some see as unflattering, stereotypical portrayals of Jews and Judaism.

title: Third World Ecology Investments Sought
description: Armed with Federal loan guarantees, a private partnership is seeking investors for third world business ventures with environmental goals that are as green as a dollar bill.

title: New Top Management Is Appointed at Eaton
description: William E. Butler was promoted to chief executive of the Eaton Corporation yesterday. He assumes the title from James R. Stover, who is also chairman.

title: BAKER ASKS DELAY ON ISRAEL AID BID
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, having failed to persuade Israel to postpone its request for $10 billion in housing loan guarantees until after a planned peace conference in October, appealed to Congress today to hold off for a time on the Israeli request.

title: General Cinema Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31

title: Read All About It! A Petrified Press in New Guise
description: On Friday, the newspaper called Leningradskaya Pravda, the organ of the Central Commmittee of Leningrad's Communist Party, quietly died.

title: In Which Timorous Growers And Frail Roses Defy Beetles
description: WHEN my father went into the hospital last summer, the Japanese beetles decimated his roses. It was almost obscene how much they enjoyed themselves, mating on the deep green leaves, burrowing into the blossoms.

title: Texas Mother Gets 15 Years In Murder Plot
description: Wanda Webb Holloway pleaded for mercy today, but a jury sentenced her to 15 years in prison for trying to arrange a killing to further her daughter's ambitions as a junior high school cheerleader.

title: Erich Schatzki, 93, A Designer of Aircraft
description: Dr. Erich Schatzki, an internationally known aeronautical engineer and aircraft designer, died Aug. 28 at a nursing home in Palo Alto, Calif. A resident of Palo Alto, he was 93 years old.

title: Jockey, 69, Retires
description: He is only 69 years old and has spent just 45 years in the saddle, a full three decades short of his career goal, but WILLIE CLARK , the nation's oldest active jockey, has decided to retire tomorrow after his 10,630th race.

title: Thomas Tryon, Who Quit Acting For a Writing Career, Dies at 65

description: A television commercial that supports Judge Clarence Thomas's nomination to the Supreme Court continued to generate political sparks today because of its harsh attacks on three Democratic Senators. President Bush personally spoke out against the advertisement, which is sponsored by two conservative groups, calling it offensive and counterproductive.
